content: Air quality refers to how clean or polluted the air around us is. It is determined by the concentration of pollutants in the air, such as particulate matter, nitrogen dioxide, sulfur dioxide, carbon monoxide, and ozone.
Good air quality is essential for human health, the environment, and climate. Poor air quality can cause diseases, reduce life expectancy, damage crops, and contribute to climate change.
CPCB AQI categories: 0-50 Good, 51-100 Satisfactory, 101-200 Moderate, 201-300 Poor, 301-400 Very Poor, 401-500 Severe.
US EPA AQI categories: 0-50 Good, 51-100 Moderate, 101-150 Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups, 151-200 Unhealthy, 201-300 Very Unhealthy, 301-500 Hazardous.
PM2.5 are fine particles smaller than 2.5 micrometers. They can penetrate deep into the lungs and bloodstream, causing respiratory and cardiovascular diseases.
PM10 are coarse particles smaller than 10 micrometers. They cause coughing, throat irritation, and worsen asthma when inhaled.
NO2 is a reddish-brown gas mainly from vehicle exhaust and industrial activities. It irritates lungs, reduces lung function, and increases asthma attacks.
SO2 is released from coal burning and refineries. It causes coughing, throat irritation, and triggers asthma and bronchitis.
CO is a colorless, odorless gas from incomplete combustion. It reduces oxygen supply in the body, causing headaches, dizziness, and even death at high levels.
Ground-level ozone forms when NOx and VOCs react in sunlight. It causes chest pain, coughing, shortness of breath, and lung damage.
Children are especially vulnerable to air pollution as their lungs are still developing. Exposure can reduce lung growth, trigger asthma, and cause long-term respiratory problems.
Elderly individuals are at higher risk because of weaker immune systems and existing health conditions. Pollution exposure increases risk of heart attacks, strokes, and chronic lung diseases.
Air pollution exposure during pregnancy can lead to low birth weight, premature birth, and developmental problems in children.
Vehicles emit NO2, CO, and particulate matter. Traffic congestion in cities is a major source of poor air quality.
Factories, power plants, and refineries emit SO2, NO2, and particulate matter, contributing significantly to urban pollution.
Burning of crop residue, wood, and waste releases large amounts of PM2.5, CO, and VOCs, particularly in rural and agricultural regions.
Natural sources of pollution include dust storms, volcanic activity, and wildfires, which can raise particulate levels significantly.
When AQI is 0-50, the air is safe. No precautions are needed.
When AQI is 51-100, the air is satisfactory, but unusually sensitive people should limit outdoor exertion.
When AQI is above 150, everyone should limit outdoor activities. Children, elderly, and patients with lung or heart disease should stay indoors.
N95 or N99 masks are effective against fine particles like PM2.5. Cloth masks and surgical masks do not provide effective protection against air pollution.
Using air purifiers, sealing windows, and ventilating during low-pollution hours can reduce indoor pollution exposure.
India’s National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) specify limits: PM2.5 annual 40 µg/m³, PM10 annual 60 µg/m³, NO2 annual 40 µg/m³, SO2 annual 50 µg/m³.
US EPA standards: PM2.5 annual 12 µg/m³, PM10 daily 150 µg/m³, NO2 annual 53 ppb, SO2 75 ppb (1-hour).
WHO recommends the strictest standards: PM2.5 annual 5 µg/m³, PM10 annual 15 µg/m³, NO2 annual 10 µg/m³.
PM2.5 refers to fine particulate matter smaller than 2.5 micrometers. They are dangerous because they penetrate deep into lungs and enter the bloodstream.
AQI helps people understand daily air pollution levels and take precautions to protect health. It simplifies complex pollution data into a single number.

subtopic: How does air pollution affect health?
